sections.title: Design Your Debt Payoff Plan
sections.subtitle: Compare snowball, avalanche, and hybrid strategies to pick your path

sections.title: What You'll Do
items: List every debt with balance, APR, and minimum payment
Calculate timelines using snowball and avalanche methods
Evaluate trade-offs between motivation and math
Build a payoff tracker you can update monthly

sections.title: Snowball vs. Avalanche
sections.content: The snowball method targets the smallest balances first, creating psychological wins. The avalanche method targets the highest APR first, saving money on interest. Both work if you stay consistent; choose the one that keeps you motivated to stick with the plan.

sections.title: Hybrid Strategy
sections.content: Start with one or two quick snowball wins, then switch to avalanche to maximize interest savings. This approach blends momentum with mathematical efficiency.

sections.title: Gather Your Numbers
sections.content: Create a table with columns for lender name, balance, APR, minimum payment, due date, and notes. Include any promo rates and when they expire. Total up your minimum payments and decide how much extra you can put toward the focus debt each month.

sections.title: Build Your Payoff Tracker
steps: List debts from smallest balance to largest in one column and from highest APR to lowest in another. This gives you the snowball and avalanche orders side by side.
For each debt, calculate months to pay off using both strategies. Use an online calculator or spreadsheet: Payment = minimum + extra (focused on one debt at a time).
Pick the strategy that gets you debt-free fastest while keeping you motivated. Circle it and note your target debt-free date.
Create a monthly progress log. Each month record starting balance, payment made, and ending balance for your focus debt.
Set calendar reminders for payment due dates and a monthly review session to celebrate progress and reallocate extra funds.

sections.title: Staying on Track
sections.content: Automate minimum payments to avoid late fees, then schedule your extra payment right after payday. When a debt is paid off, roll that full payment amount to the next debt in line. Keep an emergency fund so unexpected expenses don't force you to pause the plan.

sections.title: Pro Tip
sections.content: Call lenders to request a lower APR once you've made 6-12 on-time payments. Even a 1-2% reduction can shave months off your payoff timeline.
